articles.headline: Fox Viewers May Be Graying, but Their Passion Still Pays
articles.snippet: The median age of a Fox News viewer is over 65, which could be a cause for concern given that advertisers aim for the 25-to-54 age bracket.
articles.abstract: The median age of a Fox News viewer is over 65, which could be a cause for concern given that advertisers aim for the 25-to-54 age bracket.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox News continues to be near the top in cable television in terms of the number of viewers it attracts, but it is near the top in another category, too: the median age of its audience is among the oldest in television.

articles.headline: Strong Quarter for Netflix, but Investors Hit Pause
articles.snippet: The company gained 630,000 subscribers in the United States in the spring, but its shares fell in after-hours trading as some investors wanted even higher subscriber additions.
articles.abstract: The company gained 630,000 subscribers in the United States in the spring, but its shares fell in after-hours trading as some investors wanted even higher subscriber additions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock price for Netflix has more than doubled this year as investors placed bets that the company would just keep growing and growing. And sure enough, Netflix reported on Monday that it gained 630,000 subscribers in the United States in the spring, thanks in part to people who signed up to watch “Arrested Development,” the Fox sitcom that it revived in May.

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Inquiry Into Big Banks’ Storage of Commodities
articles.snippet: Companies that shuffle large stores of commodities to benefit from higher prices are being asked to retain documents related to the practice.
articles.abstract: Companies that shuffle large stores of commodities to benefit from higher prices are being asked to retain documents related to the practice.
articles.lead_paragraph: A tactic devised by Goldman Sachs and other financial players that has inflated the price of aluminum — and ultimately cost consumers billions of dollars — is coming under federal scrutiny.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and David Kocieniewski

articles.headline: A Towering Fine for Naught, as the S.E.C. Tracks Cohen
articles.snippet: Why did Mr. Cohen pay more than half a billion dollars to settle a case that now appears far from settled?
articles.abstract: Why did Mr. Cohen pay more than half a billion dollars to settle a case that now appears far from settled?
articles.lead_paragraph: “We’re willing to pay $600 million because we have a business to run and don’t want this hanging over our heads with litigation that could last for years.”

articles.headline: Three Men, Three Ages. Which Do You Like?
articles.snippet: Age discrimination complaints filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have risen and a method for calculating age discrimination in the workplace and elsewhere remains elusive.
articles.abstract: Age discrimination complaints filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have risen and a method for calculating age discrimination in the workplace and elsewhere remains elusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: It turns out that a young Max and a middle-aged Max can get away with saying things that an old Max cannot.

articles.headline: A Legal Bane of Wall Street Switches Sides
articles.snippet: Robert S. Khuzami is following the quintessential Washington script: an influential government insider becoming a paid advocate for industries he once policed.
articles.abstract: Robert S. Khuzami is following the quintessential Washington script: an influential government insider becoming a paid advocate for industries he once policed.
articles.lead_paragraph: When he left his role as Wall Street’s top federal enforcer, Robert S. Khuzami began a long courtship with a who’s who of the legal world.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Prices Fuel Outrage in Brazil, Home of the $30 Cheese Pizza
articles.snippet: From bus fare to rent, the price of living in Brazil keeps rising, and the push-back against increases has escalated from shopping abroad for cheaper goods to staging protests.
articles.abstract: From bus fare to rent, the price of living in Brazil keeps rising, and the push-back against increases has escalated from shopping abroad for cheaper goods to staging protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Shoppers here with a notion of what items cost abroad need to brace themselves when buying a Samsung Galaxy S4 phone: the same model that costs $615 in the United States is nearly double that in Brazil. An even bigger shock awaits parents needing a crib: the cheapest one at Tok & Stok costs over $440, more than six times the price of a similarly made item at Ikea in the United States.

articles.headline: Drug Research in China Falls Under a Cloud
articles.snippet: GlaxoSmithKline’s problems in China may be not just about its sales practices. They may also concern its research, an internal audit indicates.
articles.abstract: GlaxoSmithKline’s problems in China may be not just about its sales practices. They may also concern its research, an internal audit indicates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Executives at the British drug maker GlaxoSmithKline were warned nearly two years ago about critical problems with the way the company conducted research at its drug development center in China, exposing it to potential financial risk and regulatory action, an internal audit found.
